@tashakaminsky She spent the latter half of her life in and out of institutions. He pretty classically blamed her for all his problems. And tbf Zelda herself was the opposite of perfect (she was very racist for a start) So that’s the short version of how all these folks are the worst 26/26 https://t.co/X6p0s0KYvf

@tashakaminsky Right about the same time he was working on a book using the same source material (her diaries). He pulled some shady shit & had his publisher pub her work in a way that it did nothing even tho it was pretty decent. This coincides with one of her mental health crisis. 25/

@tashakaminsky Submitted stuff to his agent for publication and it was well received. He convinced her that she should publish under HIS name. For reasons. So some of her short stories are attributed to him. Yes really. Then she decided to write a wholeass novel and pub it under her name. 24/

@tashakaminsky She decided she wanted to ALSO be a writer and he Lost His Shit. Because again: her existence was entirely his to mine for creative works. She wasn’t ALLOWED to use her experiences for her own purposes because HE might need them for same. She went behind his back and —23/

@tashakaminsky Then he would write about what happened from the perspective of the martyred person who just wants to love this exotic flame. At one point Zelda was having SERIOUS medical issues due to an ovarian situation and he basically told her she was a drama queen. 22/

@tashakaminsky He famously stole her journals and lifted whole passages verbatim to use in his work. So basically if he writes something pretty, I assume it’s Zelda’s. He regularly encouraged her to hyper focus on something and then gaslit her into mental health crisis. 21/

@tashakaminsky But that’s likely apocryphal. Anyway. Eff Scott would literally be nothing without his wife. He was a not-well-known author prior to his marriage to Zelda. Zelda became one of the It-Girl flappers of the age. Eff Scott is on record as feeling Zelda’s experience is his. 20/

@tashakaminsky But he regularly married, cheated, divorced, married, wash, rinse, repeat. For some reason Eff Scott really glommed onto Hemingway when they were ex-pats in France together. Eff Scott REALLY wanted Hemingway to like him. He also may have offered to let Hemingway at his wife. 19/

@tashakaminsky @EvePendle Hemingway was a BLAZING misogynist who spent half his time going out of his way to prove his manhood in any way he could. It’s been pointed out to me that he struggled with his gender identity pretty seriously throughout his life so I won’t get too far into that 18/

@tashakaminsky @EvePendle Now, Eff Scott and Hemingway. These fucks. Again I’m not going to talk about the merits of their writing (other than one thing in particular re: eff Scott that I’ll get to in a minute) or their blatant antisemitism or racism because again—that’s not a surprise. 17/

@tashakaminsky Basically, Bysshe had audacity. And I get so heated about this @EvePendle has made it a blanket rule I’m not allowed to read anymore biographies about them for blood pressure purposes 🤣16/

@tashakaminsky Mary declines. I forget to mention her sister and Byron got together on the first place because her sister told Byron Mary would totally want to fuck him. I think Mary was still pregnant at the time. 15/

@tashakaminsky This became a pattern, btw. She got pregnant more than once and Bysshe and her sister knocked boots. The second or third time this happened they were in England and Bysshe decides so Mary won’t feel left out his best friend (not Byron) should seduce her. The guy tries it. 14/

@tashakaminsky They make it to Italy. Bysshe finds himself no longer attracted sexually to his super pregnant wife and begins an affair with her sister. Cause free love, remember. And whenever Mary mentions concerns she’s reminded that her MOM SAID blah blah blah. 13/

@tashakaminsky She says no. I’m sure you’re shocked. Anyway. Mary’s sister flirts with Bysshe. Mary falls pregnant. They’re making they’re way to Italy. Bysshe rolled his ankle on the road so PREGNANT MARY and her sister have to walk while he rides the donkey. 12/

@tashakaminsky Remember: Shelley’s actual wife is still in England- still pregnant. Shelley magnanimously offers to let her join their “merry band” in “friendship” b/c while he doesn’t want her anymore he isn’t an asshole apparently. That he needed $ had nothing to do with this I’m sure. 11/

@tashakaminsky Seduces teenage Mary Shelley. She loses her virginity on her mother’s grave. Totes romantic. He and Mary (& her sister who is also obsessed with Shelley and weirdly feels she’s entitled to Wollstonecraft’s legacy even tho she’s not relayed to her AT ALL) fuck off to France. 10/

@tashakaminsky I know I said Byron is the Actual Worst but Shelley holds the title of Most Pathetically Awful. Dude was married when he met Mary. Dude was obsessed with Wollstonecraft (a lot of ppl were, Tbf) dude decides free love is a thing. So even tho his ACTUAL WIFE is pregnant he —9/

@tashakaminsky That’s his greatest hits. Now SHELLEY. Father of the modern emo. King “ain’t shit” his damn self. Shelley is worse. Shelley is a classic example of when a certain kind of guy convinces himself he’s progressive but he’s not. He’s great at using vocab for his own purposes. 8/

@tashakaminsky Where he left her for “education” basically never saw her again, and then when she died tragically of typhus (or something, maybe cholera? It was a typical disease of the time) had the nerve to have a depressive spiral about the death of the kid he had zero interest in. 7/

@tashakaminsky WRT using Mary Shelley’s sister as a side piece: she got pregnant as one does. The only way he would acknowledge the child as his own was if she (Clara, the mom) signed a paper swearing she would leave him alone forever & never see her kid. He then sent said child to a nunnery 6/

@tashakaminsky But he was a terrible enough human that his ACTUAL WIFE hated him so much she refused to let his daughter have anything to do with anything in the humanities. This is partly why Ada Lovelace was a math genius. 5/

@tashakaminsky *crap that should have been 3

—Shelley because he wanted to bone Mary. Because Wollstonecraft. He continued to bang Mary’s sister because she was there and she made it known she was Wollstonecraft adjacent. I’m not touching the more inflammatory stuff like possible incest. 4/

@tashakaminsky He was a consummate shit-stirrer who had affairs on top of affairs. He basically goaded at least one of his lovers into at least one mental health crisis and used society to shame her in the bargain. He was so obsessed with Wollstonecraft (remember: humanist) he befriended—4/

@tashakaminsky But they’re all terrible people. Byron in particular is the Actual Worst. Thanks to the birth lottery he entered this world with a title and a lot of cash. He chose to be a creative type who SAID he was into humanist ideals, but he MEANT only as pertains to himself. 2/

@tashakaminsky Okay, so. The short version of this rant is that all of these men were overly privileged cis-white dudes in a time when mediocrity paid more dividends than usual. I’m not bothering to dissect any of their writing abilities. None of them would be lit-canon if their work sucked. 1/

Not to center myself, but to be sure the people I care about know they have support. I guess what I’m saying is, if I’m only for myself what am I and if not now, when? 14/14

I got a small taste of what happens when you disagree with a Nice White Lady. On the NWL scale it was probably a 2 out of 10. And it fucked me  up. I’m going to work on stepping in sooner when I see these kinds of interactions happening to others. 13/

I don’t really have a point to this thread, other than that as I said I’m thinking thoughts and trying to work out everything that happened yesterday so that I can better support people when I see it happening to them. 12/

Also a privilege: I am a 38 y/o white woman who has made it this far without experiencing this. Many of the white women I know who do not have any kind of marginalization will NEVER experience this. The Nice Culture protects them. 11/

I was really lucky in that I had a group of badass people on the group chat I could vent to. I had multiple people on this app who felt empowered enough to also respond to the person and try to deflect or diffuse. Tbh both of those are MASSIVE privileges.  10/
And then you get pissed all over again because you’re angry at them and then you’re angry at yourself and that leads to resentment. 9/

Which. I’m not going to lie: that felt gaslightey as hell. I was doubting myself and I was doubting my reactions and also doubting reality. This really can’t be overstated enough—when someone has a take THAT WRONG you really do start going “wait am *I* wrong?” 8/

So I spent half the interaction genuinely wondering if she was being outright antisemitic or if she was just centering herself in a greater discussion that wasn’t intended to be about her. (I QT’ed her original tweets to make a general point, not to attack her personally) 7/

What’s especially anomalous here is that I actually don’t know if the person yesterday even realized I was Jewish. Yes. I told her. But she did not do the overt things one would typically expect to see were that the case. 6/

And then there’s the knowledge that they’re absolutely trying to get other people to protect them and go after you. In my case the person didn’t have a following so that wasn’t a real issue, but I’ve seen this go so bad so fast for more than one of my friends. 6/

You can’t anticipate the outrage and powerlessness that is someone COMPLETELY missing your point and centering themselves. On the one hand, you want to make fun of them b/c WTF IS ANYONE SEEING THIS, but you know based on how the person is responding that’s unsafe. 5/
I have never said that this kind of behavior isn’t a problem, but the fact of the matter is, until you are on the receiving end of it, there’s no way to truly prepare for it. 4/

What I’m trying to articulate here is that I thought I was prepared. I’ve been on the receiving end of manipulative, toxic behaviors for years & I’ve had a shit load of therapy. I still wasn’t prepared. Not just for how angry the other person was, but my instinctual responses. 3/

I want to be really careful here because a lot of people smarter than me have already made these points. And when I see it happening to others, I try to step in and support. I am not trying to say “you need to pay attention to this because it happened to me, a white woman.” 2/

Thing I’ve been thinking about a lot since yesterday’s little dust up with the phd candidate—I made the joke to someone that I got “white-womaned” and it was instructive because that’s never happened to me before (because I’m a who’re woman). It sucked, but it was instructive. 1/

If you had…
we have a responsibility to leave this world better than we found it. i think i can safely say the world is better without more nazis/slaveholders. 15/15
we read fiction because we want to see the world as it *could* be, not as it *is*. 14/15

I can hear you itching to tell me how in reality sometimes that's how people really do reach things kinds of realizations and this is where I remind you that if you were writing reality you would be writing memoir. not fiction. 13/15

and if they need to fall in love with a marginalized person to realize that marginalized people are people who deserve respect, well... honestly, fuck them. because that's about the most unsexy thing I've read. 12/ 15
because if they were loudly decrying the institution that was the reich, they would have been shot. that's just reality. 11/15

at some point we have to accept that existing inside an institution without actively trying to blow that institution apart loudly and with great vigor, then we are culpable. we perpetuate harm simply by using the stationary. so your "good" character isn't good. 10/15
it does not matter that the main character is a "good" nazi. or "good" slave holder. if they were truly a "good" one they wouldn't BE one. full stop. 9/15

so books placing nazis or slave owners as the central, sympathetic character is actively harmful. especially when the intent of the book is to glorify this person. its easy to say "well look at how they've suffered on page" but LOOK AT WHAT SUFFERING THEY CAUSE. 8/15

if the intention is to tell a love story, then hurting the reader, say, (not in the "she got me in the feels" way, to be clear) is an epic fail. we have to own that we cause actual trauma when we tell a story that glorifies people who traumatized entire generations. 7/15

one of the things we as authors have to own is that we perpetuate harm by putting these kinds of stories into the world. and that harm is especially egregious when the story in question is meant to do something else. 6/15

all that to say I *get* why people want to write these books. they're juicy. it's fun as an author to roll around in a character's development and pain. but that doesn't mean the reader needs to see it. 

I'll say that again: it doesn't mean the reader needs to see it. 5/ 15

sure they could do the work, and they could learn, and they could try to make amends. but for the reader the truth of what they'd done would be too much. and the reader doesn't need to see their redemption arc. 

so I ended the series. 4/ 15

I say this as a person who started a series with the best of intentions and realized halfway through book three that these characters that I cared about, that i knew were learning and growing, that I wanted to see have their HEA... just weren't redeemable. 3/15

no, of course our characters don't have to be bastions of moral turpitude. frankly, that's boring. readers want to see a character struggle and learn and grow. that's fine. but some things are irredeemable. 

I'll say that again: some things are irredeemable. 2/15

re: "not everyone deserves to be redeemed" a thread

this is an incredibly true statement. and its hard. as authors if we don't feel strongly about our characters how are we supposed to make our readers care? but we *have* to think about what characters we're writing. 1/15

Example—we spent a big part of the session with me talking about how I believe I can’t trust my own judgement. She had me give her examples. Then we considered those examples and I realized that actually, my judgement is pretty fucking sound. So this belief is habit not truth.

A thing Rolanda said to me last night that stood out: “you have to recognize if what you’re feeling is habit or truth.” 

So an exercise: Think about that thing that’s bugging you. Is what you’re feeling a habit or verifiably true?

If it’s habit, you don’t have to keep doing it.

So yeah. That’s where I am now. I’m in “nope”. Trust me, I would love to be anywhere but here. 12/12

And it’s that very specific, familiar anger that’s filled with disgust and frustration and self hatred because this happens so often. And my brain is just like “yeah, hate that for you”. Its exhausting. 11/12

And this isn’t me asking for advice because frankly the “nope” button has been an aspect of my personality for as long as I’ve HAD a personality, this is just me screaming into the void because I’m so angry with myself that we are here again. 10/12

Then there’s writing. I just… I have a deadline. And I’m on “nope”. I’m not depressed. I’m not sad. I’m not anxious. Things are actually really good right now. But nope. What do I even do with that? What CAN I do? 9/12

And that feels so shitty. Cause it could be fine or it could be “nope, done forever.” And then it’s just another in a long line of things that were part of my identity and I’m just like pfft, and? 8/12

So great, what do I do with all that stuff? Just trash it or donate it like I did with so much stuff when I moved? That is PAINFUL to think about. But here we are. And this could change. It could just suck right now and get better. But I DON’T KNOW. 7/12

It’s just “nope, bitch.” Even for stuff I ENJOY. If I tell you the amount of money I spend on planners and stickers and pens and the TIME I put into that—because I love it okay. I do. And the way I’m terrified that my brain did the thing and now it’s just “nope”. 6/12

It feels awful writing this out. This isn’t something I like about myself. In fact, I hate it. A lot. This is the thing about myself that I LOATHE. The thing I hope nobody ever finds out. My brain will just DECIDE “nope” and no matter what I do, no matter how I mentally beg-5/12

It’s not just routines like my beauty regimen. It’s responding to messages from friends or remembering to reach OUT to friends. Day job stuff. And writing stuff. I gave myself permission to not write while I was moving but now I have no desire to write AT ALL. 4/12
Case in point: I’ve started and stopped this thread three times and I’m only on tweet 3. 🙃 3/12

Because now I’m rudderless and it feels impossible to get back into that groove that I was in where things were working and I felt like I had my shit together. And this is so, so common for people with brains like mine. But it sucks HARD. 2/12

The hardest thing for me about the last few months (like since November) has been that every single one of my daily routines have gone pfft. While I was moving I gave myself permission to do this but for my ADHD brain, this was probably the worst thing I could have done. 1/12

I completely understand why ANY form of energy work would be potentially suspect. But it’s important to remember that not all traditions look like Christianity. So perhaps consider stepping out of your comfort zone. You might be pleasantly surprised. 7/7

I would say this is a bit in line with when someone in a Christian tradition offers prayer (some Christian traditions include anointing with oils and such, which for me personally is triggering so I would decline) but if you are of a tradition that has been burned by that 6/7

I’m saying these things because asking for help and allowing others to help me are hard lessons I’m still learning because hyper independence and trauma. I know I’m not the only one. I am throwing this out there for you to think about too, b/c this is non-traditional “help” 5/7

Also I learned some things about her I didn’t know which get added to my “she’s one of the coolest people I know” arsenal. So even if I was a person who felt woo was nothing but shiny rocks and jazz hands (I’m not) those things would have value for me. 4/7

So on a basic fundamental level this was an energy exchange, I was allowing a friend to do something for me that was significant to her regardless of my feelings on her tradition. It deepens our friendship, and it sparked conversations on things we don’t usually talk about. 3/7

A dear friend of mine offered to do a clearing for me yesterday and I was curious how it would work because we’re in different states, but it took about an hour and was very cool and when I tell you I slept better last night than I have in. AGES. 2/7

If you have a friend who does any kind of woo or energy work and they offer to do a working for you—let them. Consent is important of course, so if it doesn’t resonate with you say no, but if it DOES, let your friend do that working. You may be surprised at the results. 1/7

And part of this is anxiety brain latching onto a new focus, and part of it is ADHD brain, and also my relationship to food being just generally fucked up because meal planning is a joke that ends in me planning and prepping and then not wanting it and food going to waste. 9/10

Cut to when I figured out the deli meat and fruit and cheese was a great lunch. So I’ve been eating more which is great because my body needs fuel and remembering to eat is a good thing. This also means my body has adjusted to GETTING ACTUAL FOOD REGULARLY AGAIN 6/10

And it’s REALLY hard for me to see any kind of actual meal as a good decision because while I know what I am doing is bad, it’s showing results that are getting positive reinforcement and hello dopamine slot machine. 5/10

My doctor is supportive of the low carb for the PCOS b/c Tbf this IS a thing they suggest for bodies like mine. She’s also supportive of the weight loss. This means my brain has latched onto this as “yes I am doing the right thing” 4/10

Because that’s a power bar for breakfast, a power bar for lunch (maybe if I remember I usually eat breakfast at like eleven) and then whatever I have for dinner. Sometimes if my blood sugar is crashing I’ll do a protein shake. 3/10

This has meant low carb (not strictly keto, that’s too strict), and I figured out I can remember power bars during the day. The side effect has been that yes I have lost some weight, but also if you’re paying attention my body is pretty much in starvation mode 2/10

CW: disordered eating, relationships to food, weight loss.

The last third of the book deals with the aftermath of the trial, the eugenics movement in general, and the class action lawsuits in the 70’s that would eventually deal with the fact that the state could just DECIDE to sterilize whoever they wanted. It’ll piss you off.

The case of the heiress in the book was simple: her inheritance hinged on her having a child. Her mother embarked on a campaign to get her labeled “a moron” and then had her sterilized (she thought she was getting an appendectomy) so she couldn’t have a child and inherit.

If you’re unaware, it was highly, highly common for women to be sterilized without their consent in the 20th century. This practice was used mainly to control the populations of minority groups and anyone the doctors deemed “unfit” (read: rich, white, attractive, conservative).

If you’ve been paying attention to the Britney Spears Conservatorship battle, may I suggest reading The Unfit Heiress by Ann Cooper Hewitt. It outlines how a celebrity case of a forced sterilization eventually helped with reform (CW for forced sterilization and eugenics)

This is just me throwing out there some things that have helped me a LOT over the past month or so, so that they can help someone else. Also potentially helpful and costs nothing: set an hourly alarm on your phone to remind you to stretch your face/unclench. 13/14

You just need a ziploc bag and a scarf. If you want to use the vibey thing there is no shame in using your vibrator (I’m guessing you clean it regularly if you don’t talk to @msthienkim about the importance of keeping your toys clean). Yes. Seriously. Or a back massager. 12/14

If you don’t have to deal with this stuff, I know this all sounds extra as hell, but if you do hopefully one or more of these is helpful for you. And you don’t HAVE to spend money. A spoon in the freezer does the same thing as those rollers. You can recreate the ice pack. 11/14
10/14 https://t.co/OKA2r1zld6

This doesn’t even include the ice cap, which is my nuclear option for when my head pain is REALLY bad (this happens once a month at least). There are expensive ice caps for migraine out there but this is my fav budget option (it’s purple! It has a hole in the top for hair!) 9/14

And it lives on my desk. I will break it out throughout the day if I feel myself clenching my jaw. I use the smooth back end of the head and hold it against my jaw muscles so the vibes loosen things up. Also the points at the base of my skull. Huge difference. 8/14
Because the rollers and the quartz thing worked so well, I also pulled this thing I got in a Boxy Charm box  that looks kindof like this: https://t.co/L3gD97OvOy 7/14
There’s at least one yoga pose you can do for facial tension too, and I know of at least three TikTok folks who are physical therapists who deal with these kinds of muscular aches. 6/14

It’s a combination of the ice and also working those face muscles. We can talk later about the positives around crystals (take your woo judgement elsewhere) but I also use the rose quartz one as part of my skincare regimen and it also makes a HUGE difference. 5/14

And I was excited because it was a thing I wanted but now that I’m using it regularly, holy SHIT what a difference it makes. The two metal rollers live in my freezer. When my tension levels are high or I’ve been clenching my jaw all day I’ll break them out and it is BLISS. 4/14

This year for my birthday a friend gifted me this set: Ice Roller & Scraping Massage Tool 3 Pcs, Stainless Steel Face Roller and Eye Roller Skin Care For Puffiness, Body Muscle Relaxing, Relieve Fine Lines and Wrinkles https://t.co/vkg4hwWLmM 3/14
I know, sounds fake, but stay with with me. 2/14

So tl: dr—what’s a book you’ve started multiple times but haven’t been able to finish? Or a book you started and refused to finish? Or a book you’ve been meaning to finish? SHARE YOUR DNF PROUDLY. I guarantee someone else wants to know about it so they can get a copy. 7/7

The audacity, ableism, and entitlement in the phrase “readers aren’t ALLOWED to DNF a book” as though readers owe authors anything more than the price of the book (if it wasn’t loaned or gifted to them) is astronomical. I genuinely do not understand how that person thinks. 6/7

I can’t tell you how many times I’ve checked a book out of the library that I’m technically already “in the middle of”. Sometimes multiple times for the same book. It’s what works for me. And that’s okay. Perfectly acceptable. Nothing wrong with it. 5/7

But it could just as easily be that the book wasn’t what I was craving at the time and I needed a tone shift. Or maybe I genuinely didn’t like the book. Any of these are perfectly valid. This is how my brain has ALWAYS worked. It’s NORMAL for me to have 5-10 “current reads” 4/7

To me it’s just my reading style. Some books I really do just never finish. Could be anything. Most recently it’s usually that the content wasn’t great for audiobook (or maybe the narrator wasn’t my fav) and I made a mental note to get the physical copy. 3/7

I have quite literally loaned books from my collection to people with the caveat that they should not lose my dog-ear. I have picked books up YEARS after I put it down to finish. And yes, I remember the plots. (Hi ADHD quirk, we meet again) To most people this looks like DNF. 2/7

I keep thinking about the DNF convo and it still pisses me off. My reading style is such that I will start a book, get bored, put it down, and read something else. The book is marked. I know where I stopped. I can pick it up again at any time. 1/7

@RebbeSMZ That said: pro-tip from my cousin who ALSO has ADHD and who has a stellar GPA. Have 2 running to-do lists. One of stuff you are excited to do and one of stuff you hate. Alternate tasks between the two. If you need to, set a timer and when the timer dings switch it up no excuses.

@RebbeSMZ This is not to say everyone needs to be medicated. I know ADHD folks who genuinely don’t like how they feel on meds. But for me the difference is so remarkable it actually makes me sad for past-me because I wonder what she would have done with the tools I have now.

@GWCH I’m not saying it’s not awkward (cause it is), and I would be totally fine with someone going “wow the specificity here is weird”, but that’s not where the conversation went. It turned into a more generalized “ew Israel, how dare” rather than a “kids don’t think like that”.
@MoreOrLessAMess Thank you for being open to the thought process <3

@RochelleJennin7 Someone is really upset (and prompting others to be upset) about a Jewish book by a Jewish author that dropped today (which happens to be a Jewish holiday) even tho they received an ARC book to grouse that the character pretended she was a Mossad spy when she was a child.

You get to like what you like. And you get to read what you want. But I need for you to realize that when you refuse to read a book simply because a country (and it’s population) exist as a concept of lived experience in that book we hear the antisemitism. 10/10

The fact of the matter is that Israel is deeply tied to Judaism and to Jews. When you start implying that Israel doesn’t even get to exist as a fact on a page, a lot of people get uncomfortable FAST because that is typically a precursor to some really, really bad shit. 9/10

And you know what, read what you want. Everybody gets to. That’s fine. I’m not saying buy the fucking book. What I AM saying is every time this conversation comes up I have dear friends who are suddenly worried about sharing their own lived experiences in their own work. 8/10
So this idea that a Jewish kid fantasizing about being a Mossad super spy when the same joke wouldn’t be a blip on the cultural radar if they subbed CIA instead bothers me. 7/10

I don’t have answers here. I wish I did. I am not a person who will sit quietly if I see some bad shit happening. But see, most Jews I know are like that. When I tell you that some of Israel’s harshest critics are themselves Jewish, this shouldn’t be shocking. 6/10

But that doesn’t mean that there are a lot of Jewish kids who have friends they met while on Birthright who might be Israeli. Or might have  been in IDF. Does that mean those people should never breathe about those experiences EVER? 5/10

Part of representation is normalizing experience. These casual mentions are normal in the Jewish lived experience. And yes, there’s something to be said for how Zionist the religious school curriculum can be, and Birthright is it’s own beast. 4/10
It doesn’t mean I’m going to staunchly refuse to read a book because a Jewish character acknowledges that Israel is a country that happens to exist. 3/10

I absolutely get people’s scrutiny of Israel and being furious about Israel’s decisions. I am not Zionist. I am deeply, deeply critical of Israel’s choices. But that doesn’t mean I refuse to speak to a person because they happen to be Israeli. 2/10

Here’s a thing that apparently needs a mention: Jews live and exist in Israel. It’s like, a thing. Some of us have lived there. Some of us have vacationed there. Jews casually mention their family in Israel or their plans to visit. It’s a thing. 1/10

@EvanSalama What makes it even more hilarious is every now then I’ll be like “hey dad, remember when-“ and he’ll be like NO I DO NOT, but he absolutely notices when I fill in my eyebrows and will compliment them accordingly. 😂

And that’s the story of the time my dad learned a very valuable lesson about life. Here’s a pic of me and my dad from 1983 just because I love this picture and it’s the only one I have where he doesn’t look like a Methodist minister. 13/13 https://t.co/avpwNVL4Ms

And it was completely out of character and shocked the shit out of everybody. So my brother was like “you look very nice” and slunk off. And my mom was just 😳 because she didn’t know wtf either and I was just like “uh huh. What he said.” 12/13

Stopped what he was doing, turned around, stared my brother down and did a “YOUR SISTER WORKS HARDER THAN YOU WILL EVER REALIZE TO LOOK LIKE THAT IT IS A SKILL YOU COULDN’T DO IT YOU BETTER ACKNOWLEDGE HER HARD WORK AND TELL HER YOU LIKE HER EYEBROWS RIGHT THE FUCK NOW” 11/13

Anyway. Cut to two hours later and we’re all getting ready to go. I am getting into my coat and my kid brother makes a shitty crack about “you spent all that time in the bathroom getting ready and you still look like that” and my dad went OFF. 10/13
It wasn’t explicitly SAID not to tell anybody, but it was heavily implied so I didn’t immediately call my mom at wherever she was even though it was HYSTERICAL. 9/13

So here’s my dad now glaring at my makeup like it’s personally pissed on the memory of every single one of his ancestors. And me being like  “idk dad I’m just used to it, it doesn’t bother me that much”. 8/13
Y’all I nearly threw my own back out swallowing laughter. I def fucked up my eye liner and had to start over. 7/13

You know how you pluck a hair and it hurts so bad you sneeze? Yeah that happened. The man nearly took out the glass shower doors. Cusses were hurled. Babies were cursed. It was a full on Greek tragedy in that wee tiny bathroom. General themes of “WHY TF WOULD ANYONE DO THAT” 6/13
